title: Health Coverage Considerations for Early Retirement
subtitle: Learn essential strategies for managing healthcare costs before Medicare kicks in.
content:
Health Coverage Considerations for Early Retirement

If any of this is helpful, sign up for my free weekly newsletter by clicking the link in my bio.

1. Determine Your Coverage Duration

Start by knowing exactly how many years you want to cover. This seems obvious, but covering a year is drastically different than covering a decade.

2. Explore Health Insurance Options

Next, explore health insurance options via the health insurance marketplace. These plans can be expensive but may be subsidized based on your income.

3. Consider COBRA for Short-Term Coverage

If you're just looking for short-term coverage, remember you can take advantage of up to 18 months of COBRA from a previous employer. Just keep in mind, COBRA can be ridiculously expensive.

4. Budget for Healthcare Costs Early

I would budget for these costs as early as possible, using either a health savings account (HSA) or a taxable brokerage account in your 40s or 50s to earmark a health portfolio that's placed in increasingly conservative investment vehicles as you approach the point of needing to bridge that gap.

5. Ask Your Spouse to Keep Working

Or for the easiest option, just ask your spouse to keep working. Just make sure you ask really nicely!

Conclusion

By planning your healthcare coverage strategically, you can alleviate financial stress in retirement. If you have questions or want more insights, feel free to reach out!
